content.question: Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a function with <math alttext="f of 3, equals negative 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mrow></mrow></math> and <math alttext="f prime of 3, equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mrow></math>. What is the approximation of <math alttext="f of 2.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.8</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> obtained by using the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></math> ?

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
